description:
I think I have an obsession with sushi lately. I came here a few years ago and regret not getting their nigari special, so I came back here with a friend recently and decided to get it.  I got the Omakase Nigiri 12 piece, along with the Hamachi Carpaccio and Salmon Carpaccio.   The salmon Carpaccio was ok, I didn't think it was as good as the Hamachi Carpaccio, maybe because the capers on the salmon Carpaccio took away the taste of the salmon.   The Hamachi one was our favorite and the Jalapeno did not over power the Hamachi.  

The Nigiri they had that night were the following amberjack, halibut, ocean trout, kinmedai, shima aji, sardine, salmon belly, and blacktrout seaperch. The Sardine was my least favorite, it had the strongest fish taste ever.   Everything else was amazing.  Most of it had the melt in your mouth feel.  The way to gave you the order was perfect, except for the sardine.  The most amazing dish was the last two.  The salmon belly and the Blacktrout Seaperch.   It was marinated just right, the perfect amount of sweetness and it still just magically disappeared in your mouth as you bite into it.  The final desk they gave me was the uni with the roe, over sushi rice.   Even though I like uni, it still didn't take my mind off that last two nigiri dishes.     In the end I ended up ordering an extra Tamago (Seafood Castella), which I found to be just ok, not as good as other ones I had before.  The next time I'm back I'm going to save enough money and order two pieces of their Blacktrout Seaperch.  It was that amazing!
author: Belinda C.

description:
One of my favorite sushi spots in the city.

Fresh and exciting rolls and nigiri options with an omakase that's totally worth it. They also have Hitachino beer.
author: Jessica V.

description:
Absolutely love this place! I used to live 2 blocks away so would walk to it all the time. 

My favorite roll is the Salmon Citrus roll. It's so refreshing and I love the pop of flavor with the citrus lime. I didn't try all the nigiri pieces they offer, but I did try to uni several times. I absolutely LOVE uni and get it pretty much every time I go to a sushi restaurant. The uni here was so freakin good and melts.

Only con is that it's so small inside! They probably have maybe around 7-10 tables that seat about 2 per and 5-7 seats at the bar.
author: Alex C.

description: The authenticity has gone down and prices have gone way up since I visited 2 years ago. I came with my parents and got the omakase, two waiters came to explain the fish and they labeled everything completely wrong. The hamachi Kama was not fully cooked (they took it back and didn't charge us) and the fish didn't taste high quality. Was disappointed to see one of my favorite places decline :(
author: Jessica S.

description:
With all the sushi restaurants in SF, it's easy to get stuck on where to go. There's almost always a long wait for all the high quality sushi places. Daigo Sushi is also great quality with a fraction of the wait time as other places. If waiting is not your thing, you can also call them to make a reservation.

What's nice about Daigo Sushi is the balance between affordable and nice. Typically, you can expect to pay a lot when you go to a sit down sushi restaurant. Here, it's a little more affordable (still be prepared to pay more) whilst providing great quality fish. While the menu isn't expansive, there are some good choices. We got the baked salmon roll, the naruto roll, and the moriawase nigiri. The nigiri should be eaten as is so don't drench it in soy sauce and wasabi.

This restaurant is small but it's cozy and definitely a nice place to enjoy a quiet date or nice meal with a small group of friends.
author: Derek T.

description:
Came here with a girlfriend for a birthday celebratory dinner. We each ordered the omakase, and while we did find the nigiri pieces more on the smaller size, each piece was absolutely delicious and fresh! Each piece is garnished and flavored in detail that makes dipping in soy sauce unnecessary. 

We then preceded to order more because we weren't exactly that full :-). We had the Tokyo Cowboy Roll which consisted of shiitake and tempura, topped with filet mignon served with a tataki sauce on the side. Unique and delicious.. the sauce complimented the roll perfectly! 

An order of uni (1 pc/order) was also placed... DEEEELICIOUS and so fresh and creamy and umphhh. 10/10 recommend. 

Service was good, ambiance was lovely. Would love to come back to try hamachi shots, several other rolls and nigiri specials!
author: Kris C.

description:
QUALITY FISH FOR GREAT PRICE! One of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF! Daigo is popular for its nigiri sushi, but the makis and appetizers are just as good! 

My favorite rolls at Daigo are the Tokyo Cow Boy and Rainbow Roll. The Tokyo Cow Boy has filet mignon topped with tataki sauce that just melts in your mouth and the Rainbow Roll is your typical California roll topped with assorted fresh fish. Other highlights are the Aburi Saba, Saba Nigiri, and Sake Nigiri. All makis and nigiris have the perfect rice to fish ratio. Since it's maki, it's not really that filling so expect to order at least 2-3 plates or eat for taste. 

Parking isn't too bad around this area. It's more residential so you can park either with meters or street parking a few blocks away. Expect to wait if you go during busy hours. Price is alright (slightly on the higher end). I personally think it's worth it for the quality.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Yum, worth a try for you omakase lovers! Although, I was not full with just that. 

Omakase: ordered the 10 piece for $45 with my friend. It came as 5 plates, one at a time, with two different pieces to try. Everything was very flavorful and delicious. We were advised not to use soy sauce as each piece is pre-seasoned. We were devastated when we finished the last plate...it was so good and went by so fast!

So we ordered more. On to the rolls.

Tokyo cowboy roll ($16): This is a filet mignon roll with shiitake, tempura, and tataki sauce. The texture was great with a nice crunch and savory taste of meat. Definitely unique. 

There are other rolls but pretty basic: dragon, caterpillar, etc.

We were still hungry. I knew I should have pre eaten at this point haha.

We ended it with Uni. I was hesitant to try it since I haven't had great experiences before. But I'm so glad I did, thanks to the push of my friend.

Other items on the menu include hamachi and salmon carpaccio, hamachi shots, hand rolls, etc. I need to try them next time. 

Overall, I enjoyed it here, and would recommend to my Japanese food lovers.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Daigo Sushi is a sleeper yo.  While this restaurant isn't like the super expensive omakase sushi restaurants that serve you piece by piece, the quality of their rice and fish speaks for itself.  

They have a standard menu with fish that they always have in inventory; however, there is also a separate list that is composed of the fish they received for the day--usually the more expensive, exclusive, and sought-after cuts.

I always start with the hamachi shooter with truffle ponzu.  It is my absolute favorite, and I could probably pound a dozen of them in one sitting (test me).  I always go straight to the fish-of-the-day list and pick what pieces catch my eye from top to bottom.  I have two pieces tied for first place as my favorite nigiri:  the salmon belly (sake toro) and the seared A5 wagyu.  Both are a must order.  The sake toro is topped with green onions, which adds a nice complexity to the buttery salmon.  The wagyu is lightly seared and topped with truffle salt.  You cannot go wrong with their selection of mackerel and sardine nigiris either.  

I'm really bougie with my sushi, so I don't usually order rolls.  But Daigo Sushi has one roll that I really enjoy, the Tokyo Cowboy (yee haw).  It has shrimp tempura on the inside and is topped with seared beef on the outside paired with a green onion dipping sauce.  

Jessie, one of the owners, is extremely friendly and always names the type of fish as he places your plate before you.  Don't forget to order some miso ice cream or a slice of green tea cheesecake before you leave!
author: Bonnie T.

description: I was exited to try this restaurant based on the glowing reviews. We came on a Monday night with a reservation for 8 pm, and it was pretty busy. We ordered a few appetizers, the omakase and some of the rolls. The food itself was fine, but we didn't get the main part of our order until about 9:20. We sat there pretty unhappy for almost an hour. Some of the other patrons said that's part of the experience, but I wouldn't recommend coming here based on the long wait for food. The atmosphere is also loud and not very pleasant. The waiters were apologetic and comped a few items, but the damage was done and we were pretty close to walking at the hour and fifteen minute mark.
author: Josh P.

description:
Came in as a group of 3. 

Did three miso soups and edamame, which came out very quickly.

We ordered bluefin tuna 3 piece.....rainbow roll, salmon citrus, Naruto, and baked salmon.

All of them were great! 

The price was about $180 for us overall. 

I will be coming back to this place again!
author: Robert R.

description:
It's small, crowded, unassuming, and there's almost always a wait. It's a little neighborhood spot, and it's perfect.

Located in the Outer Richmond, it's certainly a five-star sushi joint, but hardly "SF's Best Sushi." I think the charm lies in the location, the service, and the high quality stuff they're doing. It's not fancy, but they've got that little corner on lock.

I've been a handful of times, sometimes to celebrate a small life victory in a group of three, or with family. There's not much room inside, so you will do well to limit your party to four at the most; two, ideal. It's a lot of neighborhood folks, but it's a little more elevated than a "swing by and pick up some rolls" kind of sushi joint.

I was going to try to recount everything I've gotten here, but it all has been so good that let me just give you some guidance: let them guide you. Grab the list of current fresh fish, and go with some interesting cuts you've never had. Nigiri or sashimi, just delight in the actual fish. They're not really roll-heavy on the menu, and you can add a seaweed salad it you want to have a little variety on the plate. Last time I was here I did just that: ordered some 8 or so pieces of nigiri based on the server's recommendation, and sat back to enjoy. Each was expertly prepared and I was able to focus on the fish and seek out the distinct flavors that each species and cut brought me.

There's a wait almost every night, but it's not huge. The most they've ever quoted me was 30 minutes, and I've just hung out twice and been seated within 15 minutes. You'll be seat to seat with other people there, but again, with a neighborhood vibe, no one is too cranky about this. The joys of the Outer Richmond are that if you need parking, it's (probably?) not going to be impossible, but I usually walk here. Clement has a bunch of great options, but when Daigo opened, it got the sushi option it was lacking. 

Not necessarily a destination sushi spot, but if you're in the 'hood and want sushi, you shouldn't mess with any other place.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I'm going to make this fairly short and sweet.

This place is f*ckin dope!

Yea it's small, yea it can get crowded. But it's homie, the fish is good, and I find it to be good value for your buck.

Hamachi shot, hell yea.
5-piece nigiri omakase, mhmmmmm
Two basic rolls
3 a la carte nigiri's 

all for just under $100? I think that's pretty good.

Santa Barbara Uni was soooooo good
Hamachi shot and nigiri omakase were bomb.

Honestly...this is just a great all around place that doesn't come off pretentious or feeling like you got ripped off.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Came here on a late Friday evening. The place is very small and was still packed even a little later into the evening, so we were lucky to have gotten a small table as we walked in.

They don't have that many options on the list, but sometimes its actually a good thing. We got a salmon avocado roll, caterpillar roll, baked salmon, and tokyo cowboy.

In my opinion, the salmon avocado roll was actually one of the best I've had ever, the fish was really fresh and soft, melt in your mouth, and one of the favorites out of even the special rolls. I thought the special rolls were decent, but not amazing. The Tokyo Cowboy, is definitely unique and a must try if possible; I enjoyed it, just because its not something you see often.

The icing on the top? Some green tea ice cream at the end. Overall, one of the favorite sushi places in the city and will come back again. Maybe get more orders of the salmon avocado. Although will try to get some of the Nigiri or some Sashimi, and maybe hand roll next time to try out more of the options on the menu as well.
author: V W.

description: Avoid the 2.5 hour bougie experience and just come here, order the fish you like and be satisfied.  Get the 12 piece omakase for 70 bucks then sub it with whatever the hell you want.  Omakase that night came with o-toro, and pretty much everything on the specials menu.  Quality here is solid AF but don't plan to leave super full.  If you got that sushi itch this place will scratch the f out of it.
author: Vince L.

description:
Expensive, but I found this to be one of those sushi places where I could literally taste the high quality in each piece of nigiri. I could taste the care and balance placed into each piece. The establishment is simple and doesn't have an overblown menu. There is absolutely no need for ordering a side of Wasabi here or soy sauce.

This place can easily burn a hole in the wallet, but I will return occasionally when I feel like rewarding myself.
author: Eduardo C.

description:
What you need to know: 
- a non-pretentious and unassuming sushi place that has 24 table seats and 6 bar seats 
- customer service is very attentive 
- accepts credit cards 
- as many reviews have noted, it is pricey, in light of the quality of fish 
- at the end, paid $70 and left hungry = the worst combination 

What we ordered:
5 piece nigiri omakase $23 - first, the rice was not well seasoned and was extraordinarily small. 4 of the 5 piece tasted bland and very similar in taste, the only one that had a distinctive taste was the mackerel. In addition, all fish were sliced very thin. This was a tremendous disappointment! 
- Amaebi (sweet shrimp), uni, fresh hotate (scallop), hamachi, salmon, hamachi belly, unagi - ordered a la carte and was much better in flavor than the omakase. Amaebi, uni and the fresh hotate were the most flavorful and distinctive tasting of the bunch. I agree with other Yelpers that the hamachi $2.75 was very good and priced well. 
- Overall, nigiri pieces were sliced thin, not outstanding in flavor and rice was not seasoned well and small. Overpriced for what you get in terms of quality.
author: Karen L.

description:
What we ordered:
california roll
spicy tuna roll
tempura roll
ika nigiri
aburi saba
dragon roll
hamachi carpaccio

My favorite dish out of the bunch was the aburi saba. The seared mackerel was tasty and fresh. Overall, everything we ordered tasted pretty good, but not the best. I've definitely tried tastier sushi rice and fresher fish elsewhere. (I'm not comparing it to Japan, of course, because that would be an unfair fight.) Would I go again? Maybe, maybe not.
author: Briana H.

description:
It's a quaint restaurant near the Golden Gate Park.  What I love about this sushi place is the variety of fish they have.  They generally have a special slip with all the fresh fish of the day.  You'll find selection that I normally won't be able to find.  The price is quite reasonable as well.  They won't charge you an arm and a leg for uni.  The ankimo nigiri was much more reasonable than I thought as well.  I love their shima aji.  I haven't tried the rolls.  However, why would you want to, when they have a wide selection of fresh fish to choose from.  

One thing that I would caution was that the rice wasn't at the right consistency or temperature.  It was a bit hard and a little too cold as well.  It may have been a bad night, so I'll try this place again.  Perhaps I can just get sashimi and avoid the rice all together.  Another thing I didn't like was the toro had some tendon leftover on the fish.  The knife work needed to be better.  The toro tasted amazing, just the piece of tendon on it left the texture a bit off. 

I'll definitely come back for any non-standard fish that I would normally try.
author: Shirley C.

description:
I came home thinking I was going to have dinner a la Trader Joe's (a pre-made Caesar salad and a mini-pizza).  The kitchen was off limits when I got home, for reasons I won't state, so opened the Yelp app to see what's nearby. Daigo was close and it had been awhile since I ate there.. so I decided this was a good opportunity to go back. 

The menu has increased the last time I was there. And they have a longer list of specialty sushi. I ordered the salmon belly nigiri from that list, and a sweet potato maki and shrimp tempura maki from the regular menu.

The salmon belly was delicious! It had a hint of wasabi that heightened the taste of fresh salmon. Though I wished I ordered the sashimi (because I would've had 3 instead of 1), I'm glad I didn't because I was full from my two other rolls.

The sweet potato was light in taste, but a bit of wasabi and soy sauce took care of that. And you can't go wrong with a shrimp tempura roll. I liked that, though my two rolls were fried, it wasn't greasy at all. 

Daigo is usually crowded whenever I pass by, but tonight it wasn't a full house and was able to get a seat at the bar. The rolls came out quickly, and I enjoyed a scoop of green tea ice cream thanks to the Yelp check-in!

Daigo is a neighborhood gem! I need to come back more often for their specials.
author: Vira P.

description: Came here for dinner with reservations with my friends and one who is a regular. The restaurant has an omakase option, but my friend opted to choose all the nigiri pieces he wanted for the table. The wagyu was one of my favorites, along with the salmon and uni. All the fish were fresh and rice was flavored right and soft. We left super filled, and service was friendly even though they ran out of a certain fish my friend put in an order for. Small spot, so definitely reserve if you can. They also have bar seating. Would love to return one day soon! Heads-up, parking is horrible around here because it took me over 30 minutes to find, so public transportation or rideshare is highly suggested.
author: Amanda C.

description: I'm not sure why Daigo has such good reviews... we ate there last Saturday night. All of the people working there were super nice but the sushi was very disappointing. Just didn't seem fresh and was a bit warm actually. We were there later in the evening so maybe they ran out of the good stuff? We actually wondered if we'd be sick from the fish (thankfully not). The best thing we had was green tea ice cream. Won't be back.
author: Jenny V.

description:
YUMMMMM. Earlier this week my cousin and I met up for dinner and she picked Daigo Sushi. I hadn't heard of it before, but I figured they have good reviews and when can you ever go wrong with sushi? Upon walking in, I made a mental note of "oh, this place is small, intimate and cute!". We had a 7pm reservation on a Monday night and the place was full. 

During our meal, we tried their Hamachi Shot, Rainbow Maki, Naruto Maki, James Maki, Unagi Nigiri, Zuke Sake Toro (Salmon Belly) Nigiri, Ikura Nigiri (Soy Marinated Salmon Roe), Hon Maguro Nigiri (Bluefin Tuna) and a few different sake selections. Their Nigiri options from the seasonal menu are on point - super fresh, high quality, melt-in-your-mouth fish. The Hamachi Shot was delicious (I LOVE truffle... But who doesn't!?) and the roll that stood out was the Naruto - something different and it was so tasty, also melted in your mouth, and I loved the healthy/light/fresh feel to the roll.

This place is more expensive than your typical sushi place, but well worth it. For everything mentioned, we spent about $115pp (including tax + tip). What tops my review off at 5 stars is the service - fantastic food and great service! I would definitely return.... **dreaming of sushi...*
author: Tiffany K.

description: Favorite weekday, weekend and for entertaining sushi spot in the neighborhood! Affordable and high quality! Staff are friendly and knowledgeable. Everyone we bring here loves it and it's a nice date night or "too tired to cook night" If my rent was cheaper I would eat here every night. Make sure to try the Hamachi Shot
author: Marcela H.

description:
One of the best sushi spots I've ever been to. Friends visiting are always blown away.

This unassuming spot is such a gem. The california hand rolls made w real crab are incredible. Their nigiri list is also top notch. 


Its hard to get a table on the weekends.
author: Ken B.

description:
This is the best sushi out there that is a step up from the neighborhood sushi place that sells CA rolls as their special but underneath the omakase Michelin's. 

My friend recommended this place and said that I should order exclusively from the specials menu. I'm a nigiri kind of girl and I love the omakase experience. When I came, there were about 20+ of really unique choices of fish. I ordered the ones that appealed to me and it came out to about fifteen pieces. Of course I got both kinds of uni! It came out to about $100. 

Service was alright... I want to come back and actually chat with the chefs and have that experience.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Hole in the wall - located on a corner. There aren't many tables inside so there can be a wait if there's a lot of people. Came here on a thursday night and waited around 20-30min. 

Get the hot sake- only $5 for the large! I got the omakase 10 pieces and a side of uni (because who doesn't like uni)!!!! DELICIOUS!!! For the price, the quality is pretty good! It's not too expensive but not cheap either. 

I really liked the selection of fish- everything looked pretty good. Sushi was really fresh so that's all that matters! I feel like this is a hidden gem!
author: Jessie H.

description:
Let's jump straight to the food...

Hamachi caropaccio - My favorite. It was so good that I couldn't stop eating it. The hamachi was fresh and the flavor was great. I will probably order this every single time I'm back.

Beef tataki - Not bad. People who like their meat medium rare will enjoy this, but I'm not a big fan of meat so I can't say much.

Caterpillar roll - Avocado was extra fresh. This roll was delicious and solid.

Dragon roll - Similar to the caterpillar roll but there's shrimp tempura. This roll was okay, but it might've been because we ate this roll last so the shrimp tempura wasn't hot anymore.

Service was average. I kept finishing my water since I was so thirsty and I had to keep asking for more. This place is a bit pricey though. Our bill was a little under $70 for two and we still had room for dessert after.
author: Julian Y.

description: Really good sushi. Pretty fresh and the tempura is really good as well. Service was fast and friendly and it's a cute little spot. Prices weren't bad at all. 10/10 would recommend and I'm glad we found this place. Definitely coming back again soon.
author: Angie C.

description:
We ordered the following items for a party of 2:

Hamachi shots (4)
Hamachi carpaccio
Uni nigiri (2)
Amaebi (2)
Salmon carpaccio
Beef tataki
Sashimi moriawase
Naruto 

I would definitely recommend the hamachi shots, hamachi carpaccio, and amaebi. The shots had just the right amount of fish to pozu ratio, with the added quail egg and crunchy rice balls. 

The naruto was an interesting dish. Refreshing, but i wish it were filled with something other than spicy tuna. Perhaps a higher quality fish filling would taste better. 

Service was great. Small place so come with 4 or less people.
author: Claire W.

description:
Ok so the issue is that when everyone finds out how bloody good this place is it will be booked all the time!

I'm calling it! Best sushi in SF! A lot of places in SF say they do sushi but they really just put up sliced fish on a plate. This place WOW! Food amazing! Beer on tap and ice cold! 

It's not a place to go if you want cooked food mostly raw bar and a few cooked starters. 

100% will go again and again when back in town.
author: Mark H.

description:
So let me begin with the food is almost Saru. Maybe it used to be $$ but it is definitely $$$ now. For instance, $20 for 2 pieces of awesom Suzuki. Not $$, so if you are looking for that, there are other places. Moriwase was "no soy sauce needed", so yea. Like that. Good, and awesome to have in the neighborhood. $90 for 2 of us left unsatiated at 3 rolls, 10 piece moriwase, 2 piece suzuki.

Also, we got there at 6:45 so lucky enough got seats, but after that it looks hard to get seats.
author: Choladeva C.

description:
Hands down the best sushi I've had in SF!!! It's been 4 days, and I'm still raving about it to my friends. Came here on a Saturday around 2pm. Was a little skeptical at first since the restaurant was practically empty (however they were about to close at 3pm). Anyways sat down and saw that they had sake flights! It comes with 3 different types sake for $15, and boy were these strong. My friend and I shared this and took a nap after haha. 

My absolute favorite thing we ordered was the Toyko Cowboy roll. It has green onions, shitake and seared FILET MIGNON & tataki sauce ... so so so good. It's a must try!! The Hanabi roll was pretty good; it's a tempura tuna roll .. deep fried goodness! These two rolls went very well together! We were still hungry so we also got the James roll which had shrimp tempura and topped with very fresh seared yellow tail and jalapenos. This roll is on the spicier side so beware if you don't like spicy! The prices were a little high but you get what you pay for. And you're pay for good quality, fresh fish here. 

I would also like to note the wonderful customer service that Daigo Sushi provides. Our server was friendly and super patient with us. Definitely will come back to try their chef's special omakase. It is a fairly small restaurant so reservations would be a good idea during peak hours.
author: Nancy C.

description: I first came here years ago when they first open. They use to open for lunch but I guess it's not busy enough during that time so now only dinner. Came here a few times and they have never disappoint. Fresh and yummy flavor. For guarantee good and fresh sushi, this is the place. My fav is their ocean trout which they were the first to introduce it to us when they first open and I love it ever since. Their ikura is the bomb! No rice needed. They flavor their own ikura. Give me a bowl of ikura and spoon and I'm happy all day ! Their Kama toro is F..goooood! Beside Hokkaido uni of course lol. Service is pretty good too. Price is descent. Not cheap or expensive. I wish I live accross the street lol.
author: Christy V.

description: Great, quality sushi that won't break the bank. My gf and I went here after getting a few recommendations from friends. Ordered a number of nigiri pieces, including salmon belly (sake toro), toro, scallop, king salmon and of course, A5 wagyu! We even went a step further and took the waiter's recommendation for nigiri that neither of us had ever heard of;delicious! The Tamago was excellent. Just wish it was served with rice like typical nigiri.
author: Huy N.

description: Food was good, different.  The hamachi shot and the naruto was really good.  We also ordered blue fin tuna and blue shrimp sashimi which was really good. Between 4 people our bill came out to be $168 and we didn't even order alcohol.  Portions are small.  Not too many options.  Left without feeling fulfilled.
author: Kenney C.

description: I thought this place was ehhhhh. Came here on a Friday night at 7 and it took us 30 min to find parking in this area. When we finally got to the restaurant there was one couple ahead of us. We were seated at 8pm. I got the Hamachi shots, spicy tuna roll, their famous Tokyo cowboy, and lastly the baked salmon. I personally thought all of their most popular rolls here were just OKAY. My favorite was their hamachi shots which were $6 for one. Customer service was alright as well. This place is pretty small there were only 7 tables and a bar which fits 4 people. I wouldn't come here again just because all the food I tried nothing stood out to me and the parking sucks.
author: Tina C.

description:
Eric does amazing sushi. My wife and I always come here to celebrate or treat ourselves. His sushi is totally michelin star quality and amazing value.

We usually order off the seasonal sushi menu. He treats many of his fish to bring out the best flavor and changes his preparations seasonally. Some of his fish is cured, or aged, or marinated. I personally love his aji preparation, as well as the regular salmon, regular yellowtail and special scallop.

He's very friendly and is happy to explain what garnishes he's putting on the fish and why he selected it.
author: Ian W.

description:
Probably one of my favorite sushi places in San Francisco. It's pretty pricey, but their sushi is always fresh and soooo delicious. I always order their nigiri specials and they are AMAZINGGGG. My favorites are the toro, wagyu beef, and salmon belly. I normally don't order salmon so if I'm saying it's good, it must be good LOL! The chef prepares the nigiri with almost like a light ponzu sauce and they recommend not adding soy sauce or wasabi. I've never added anything to it and its pretty good. Another favorite of mine is the Naruto roll. Its basically  spicy tuna, hamachi, and I think salmon wrapped in cucumber. Its soooooo good. 

The restaurant is pretty small so make sure you make reservations ahead of time esp if you have a big party. I think this place is best for date night or maybe a small group. Give this place a try and you won't regret it!
author: Kelly S.

description:
As long as you have deep pockets then you will love this place!
The sushi is excellent, and I like their baked salmon too.

Don't forget to get some edamame (soy beans) to chew on while you wait (not that it's a long wait).
I called after getting on the bus, around 45 min before getting there on a Saturday night and they had a table ready for us.

Friendly staff, bathroom available, they take cards, cool view on cooks, what's not to like.

People complaining about the fact that it's tiny must not know much about San Francisco in general... Yes, I've been to giant sushi restaurants but guess what, those had slow service and were understaffed, so I see nothing wrong with this cozy sushi bar. There's an intimate feel to it you can't get in bigger places.

I wish the opening hours were less limited though...
author: Matthew C.

description:
I've gotten take-out here once when my sis was staying with me for the weekend. It's around where I live, but we drove over to pick up the food.

Parking was difficult so ended up parking in front of a fire hydrant really quickly. When I went in at the time that they said the order was going to be ready, the guy said to wait 15 more mins. *sigh*

We got a dragon roll & a lion king roll. Both were delish.

3.5 stars
author: Amy C.

description:
Make a reservation, cause the please is a little small. It was a little stuffy as well. The service was great. The staff was friendly and check up on us and filled out water often. 

Hamachi shot is a must. I also ordered the 10 piece omakase. It was decent quality for the area, but I wouldn't drive out of my way to go.
author: Chantel H.

description:
Came here with a friend and we seriously couldn't stop eating! Really fresh fish and attentive service. Since it was just the two of us, we only ordered nigiri because we knew getting rolls wouldn't have been worth it. My favorites of the night were:
-Hamachi Shots - must order!
-Toro - ordered it twice bc it was that good.
-Wagyu
-Salmon Belly - ordered it twice as well!
-Uni

We also ordered scallop, mackerel, sake, and negitoro.

Daigo is pretty pricey so I'm not sure if I would come back too many times when I can get more value for my money elsewhere, but this place is a must try. Thanks Daigo for a great meal!
author: Elisa S.

description:
My coworkers told me about this place by my house so I decided to check it out. I was craving sushi and this place was exactly what I needed. 

The sushi is excellent quality, the atmosphere is relaxing and chill all around, and the service is wonderful. It's a pretty tiny location with probably around 20+ occupancy including the sushi bar. 

Plenty of drink menu options consisting of a variety of sake and beer. We ordered a pitcher of beer. So much beer for two people I would say!

Also, we ordered the caterpillar and the spider roll. Both tasted great! Also, we got the green tea cheesecake with sesame ice cream on the side. It was so tasty. Everything we ordered here was wonderful. This will definitely be my new sushi place in town!
author: Lori R.

description:
You know how there are those sushi restaurants where you pay $7+ for 2 pieces of fish (sashimi) and wonder how the hell you walked away dropping $150+ on fish that you can order anywhere? 

THIS IS NOT THAT PLACE! The fish is not only EXTREMELY fresh, but they take the time to make sure that they brush each piece of fish with perfectly paired sauce that does not overwhelm the fish or take away from it but makes it a little slice of heaven! 

trick to knowing a sushi place is great? NO SOY SAUCE REQUIRED!!! The thought doesn't even cross your mind as you devour each delicious morsel of sushi. This is when you discover how talented sushi chef's truly are. taking something that is already perfect on its own (raw fish) and adding to it without discrediting its constitution isn't easy. They do a great job here!

want to try ACTUAL sushi (no soy sauce needed)??? Go here!
author: Brittney G.

description:
Fresh fish
Fish is cut well (not uneven or too thick)
Fair portions for the price
Simple and clean rolls (NOT DROWNED IN SAUCE!).
Good fish to rice ratio
Quick, friendly, and efficient service

Recommend!

Favorites:
Salmon citrus roll - buttery salmon perfectly contrasted with a small thin slice of lemon. YUM!
Creamy scallop roll
author: Emily C.

description:
I'm a sushi snob and this place is one of my favorite. Little corner spot in the outer Richmond that beats most of the fancy Japanese restaurants in quality and service city wide.
The menu is simple, nothing overwhelming, but what they serve is just out of this world. Always fresh and well prepared by the chefs. 
Highly recommended!
author: Bianca W.

description:
This place is small but we were lucky in a rainy night that it wasn't crowded. Greeted by staff immediate, we were tended to very tentatively. Recommendations on food were totally on point. 

We had the Hamachi shots, King Salmon, Local Uni, Omakase 5 piece nigiri, unagi nigiri, Tokyo Cowboy, Hamachi Carpaccio, Hamachi Kama, Naruto, and Salmon skin hand roll. 

EVERYTHING was delicious. I can't wait to go back. The sushi was so fresh and full of flavor. These delectable delights were a great surprise as it was our first and definitely not the last time there!  Prices were also pretty reasonable. There were three of us and everything was really easy to share. Highly recommend dining here! 

Only draw back is parking can sometimes be difficult in this area.
author: Sandy N.

description: Cute little Sushi restaurant with amazing food. It was super fresh melted in my mouth.
author: Huong N.

description:
4.5 stars round up Had a late night dinner with my daughter in San Francisco at Daigo Sushi. Tiny sushi place in the Richmond district with a large selection of exotic fish. We had the asked the sushi Chef to make us a $60 sashimi plate with a selection of the special fish of the day. It was excellent! Along with the sashimi we had Uni, Hamachi shots, Neruto Roll, and the Niguri Moriwase. All were fresh and well presented. Great little find in the Richmond for a sushi meal. 

Service was excellent. Parking is crazy bad but there is paid lot 2 blocks away for $8.
author: George F.

description:
Meh, this place was not the best sushi I have ever had... I ordered the maki salmon roll and the salmon didn't taste right.. was it supposed to be warm? I also ordered the caterpillar, dragon, and baked salmon roll. Although the maki salmon wasn't as great, I would probably say that the baked salmon roll was probably one of the best I've eaten of that kind. I think the caterpillar and dragon roll were too similar so that's probably why I didn't enjoy my experience as much as I would like. 

Service was great, prices are not on the "cheap" end and I would recommend AYCE sushi if you eat a lot since it came out to be around the same price anyways.
author: Amy L.

description: This was my favorite sushi restaurant for a while. Good quality sushi. But the last couple times I've tried to call for pick up they said they are too busy. This makes no sense. It's a tiny restaurant and he said they had four chefs behind the counter. I'm not ordering from them anymore and that's disappointing.
author: Chuck K.

description: One of my favorite places for sushi in the Bay Area. Low key. Low prices. No problems getting reservations.
author: Karl K.

description:
This place is delicious! 
Appetizers: 
Hamachi shots are a must here, the hamachi to their sauce is such a great combo! 
Beef tataki is a must as well, their spicy sauce that comes on the side is
We also ordered their ankimo which was good but It just wasn't the best for me. 

Nigiri:
UNI nigiri is always a great way to start, their Japanese one is definitely better than their local one. It's sweet and creamy

Toro nigiri is SOOO bomb here!! It's a fatty blue fin Tuna that just melts in your mouth! 

Salmon nigiri is always a safe route to eating sashimi/ nigiris

Wagyu nigiri, oh my goodness save this for last because it is that good. If they have if be sure to order it before they run out. You will not be sorry! Wagyu beef is a very tender fatty beef that just melts in your mouth when you take that first bite. I ensure you will want to order more of this. 

Dessert:
Vanilla crepe cake although this is not the best crepe cake I have ever had, it was a great way to end my meal. It wasn't too sweet nor bland. 

Service:
Service wise, they were great! I had originally ordered 4 toro nigiris, but sadly they only had two left. The guy who came to serve us our food was very apologetic,and gave us two of their local UNI sashimis to try. Even though I did not care for the local uni, it was the thought of him doing this gesture that matters. I wish I got his name, unfortunately I forgot to ask, but he is always there!
author: Elsa W.

description: I love the sushi and service here. The fish are really fresh and the nigiri rice is good. Their customer service is great. They are courteous. Definitely would come back for sushi here.
author: Amy T.

description: Disclaimer: I'm not that big on sushi, it's not my go-to dinner and I only go when other people want sushi. That likely makes me a tougher crowd that the average sushi-goer but it also means I only enjoy really good sushi. I thought the flavors of the sushi here were not good, fishy, and worst of all the consistencies were off. I even found the california roll gross, it was too full of mayonnaise and felt chewy in my mouth. I don't like writing negative reviews but I honestly did not enjoy any part of this meal aside from the miso soup.
author: Fleur R.

description:
A secret hideout of unfussy sushi masters. The seafood quality here is A/A+ & better than even trendier spot like PABU / ICHI+NI downtown. It's also cheaper, but not *as* cheap as the dingy decor would lead you to be believe! So don't be misled on both its stunning sushi and its secretly-$$$ price.

I was skeptical of the non-Japanese staff and the really un-auspicious design choices in this space, but the $40 ten-piece sushi omakase blew me away. That is by far the best deal in this sushi bar, and the same quality/tastiness would probably cost $60 at a trendier spot. Hirame, scallop, and all the varieties of madai/kurodai/kinmedai were expertly seasoned with light shiso/yuzu/searing. Salmon roe is also authentically marinated to be umami rather than overly salty.

You'll notice that the penchant for of zealously scoring/searing the fish flesh is a trend more commonly found in upscale sushi places in Chinese speaking countries (Taiwan / Hong Kong / China) than in Japan itself. That's fine. It's still very good.

If you start ordering catch-of-the-day nigiri pieces individually, this place could get as expensive of the big downtown sushi masters (though still good, you might not want to pay so much at a crowded hole-in-the-wall with no ambiance).
author: Ken H.

description:
We went here for dinner with a group of friends during my 1-day trip in SF. The place is quite small so it was hard to get a table for 6. We sat near the door and it's quite cold to be honest whenever someone opened it to walk in or out.

All of the sushi we had were really fresh and good! The hamachi shots were especially very tasty and all of my friends really loved those.
author: Anh L.

description:
Came here spontaneously, after going to China Beach and decided to yelp nearby places to eat! 

I got the seafood sashimi salad and it came on a bed of greens. There was a decent amount of sashimi and they all tasted nice and fresh. The ponzu sauce that came with it was great and very refreshing. My friend got the the hamachi shot which she said was delicious. She also got the Hamachi Carpaccio and naruto roll which was spicy tuna wrapped in cucumber. The presentation of everything was beautiful and artfully plated. My friend and I agreed that all the sushi was very fresh and the menu was simple and straightforward. There were no crazy rolls or anything like that because the menu really just highlighted the fresh fish.

The best thing was that we checked in on yelp and even got complimentary ice cream. They had 3 flavors red bean, black sesame, and green tea. When our ice cream came, I was surprised how they gave nice big scoops and didn't skimp since the ice cream was free. Decent prices, fresh fish, and even dessert? Definitely a good stop!
author: Joy W.

description:
Fresh, delicious, and unassuming. They have some really unique fish on the menu that you can't find in other places. 

Would definitely go back!
author: Jordan K.

description:
There is a little place near T's house that had this cult following. I don't do cult following. Despite the fact that my colleagues who had recently descended over to that same neighborhood had asked me to go there like they did. As if it's a dare. I refuse.

But still I wanted sushi that one evening so we decided to take a walk. 1.3 miles. from Inner to Outer. Arrived at this little restaurant that could very easily be mistaken to be in Japan. Quaint like Japan, but not exactly quiet like in Japan. Two ladies were having some passionate discussions about work. We got to eavesdrop. A couple, regular to this shop, grabbed two bar stools next to us. Two other couples were wrapping up at 7 PM. People eat early in this part of world.

Because it's Outer Richmond, it feels foreign, exotic and quite unlike the fanciful restaurants you'd see in the Marina, SoMa or the Mission. It's homey and practical. It is efficient. It is to the point. 

Omakase sashimi sampler. The rainbow roll. The hamachi jalapeño roll. All good quality fish, uncomplicated flavor. My favorite, however was their saba nigiri. I liked you could order nigiri in one piece. It made sense because that's how it was done in Japan and it's more appropriate to have different options.

We took our time to finish the meal and then walked back. The wind had picked up as it normally did at this time of the day. We picked up our pace.

Good sushi. No wait. Lovely spot. Fresh fish. Pleasant service.

This is not my neighborhood. But I have become quite comfortable navigating in and around it, as of late. I might just navigate myself back to this spot.
author: Victoria E.

description: Really solid sushi.   Pretty good.  We got nigiri and a couple of rolls and everything was great.
author: Michael E.

description: Very fresh fish but nothing innovative. For the lack of wow it's over priced. Between 4, we had 10 piece omakase and basically what they had as special pieces. But they're fresh but little boring. Only thing that I really liked was uni. Will not go back.
author: Michi M.

description:
Daigo has incredible sushi and a large variety of the freshest specials each day. We love checking the specials and carrying out on those nights when we can't eat in. If you can eat in, it's cozy but busy enough that you can bring your young kids and not feel out of place (just leave your stroller at home or in the car). 

We've been carrying out most Friday nights since discovering it a couple of years ago - so glad they've stayed in the neighborhood. The price is definitely worth the quality and variety you get here. When we came back from a 10-day trip to Japan, we came here a few days later and felt like we were back on our trip, it's that good.
author: Betsy A.

description:
Daigo has pretty decent sushi for the price. Be aware that they don't offer the $60 omakase at lunch - you also have to let them know about your order beforehand.

I stopped by for a quick lunch with my brother and the restaurant was pretty empty. The server was very accommodating when my brother ended up being late due to the lack of parking in the area.

I ordered the $20 5-piece nigiri omakase. The sizes are definitely on the smaller side, so don't expect to fill up on it! My omakase had fatty tuna, barracuda, amberjack, sea bream, and firefly squid.

The hamachi shooter was excellent. I wouldn't have minded a couple more of those. :)

Overall, it was a good choice for a quick and light lunch. I didn't get a chance to try their rolls but I hope to next time.
author: Kelly L.

description: I had twice really bad experience w/ this place , that's y I gave them one star. One time I walked in n tried to order to go, the waiter asked me was I picking up online order?! I said no, I wanted to order to go, then the waiter told me they don't do order to go. I was like??huh? They weren't busy n the place was kinda empty? Wonder y they do online order but no walk in order to go? Then, yesterday, I dined w/ my two kids there, I ordered few things. It took them 40mins to make just two rolls...... it was 8pm, yes, I know that time is kinda busy, but 40mins? for just two roll? Maybe I was w/ two kids n I didnt order that much they just don't take our order seriously... honestly I will never go to this place again, even I live pretty close~~
author: Rachel L.

description: Fresh and flavorful!!! Small menu, delicious sushi! Super attentive / friendly service! We'll be back!!!
author: Nicole K.

description:
It had been a while since I had sushi, so the roommate and I decided to order delivery. We ordered via Eat24.

January 2014
*James roll ($13), Spider roll ($7.50), Buri toro nigiri ($5), Ankimo nigiri ($5) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/daigo-sushi-san-francisco#aRj5G84zwLPeeFtIy5cuXQ
*Moriawase sashimi ($22) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/daigo-sushi-san-francisco#erGjF1ycj6Gt80IiXp39Uw
*Beef tataki ($10) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/daigo-sushi-san-francisco#TRYVsQAxqV-B9eM64mKZkw
*Eryngi tempura ($8) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/daigo-sushi-san-francisco#v3Zm7srKAZ9j_lzMzNmNCw

I normally don't want a full order of ankimo, so I was happy they offered an ankimo nigiri. It was rich and creamy. I enjoyed the tempura mushrooms and the buri toro had a nice fattiness to it. The sashimi was pretty good as well. I didn't really care for the beef tataki as it was dry. The roommate seemed to enjoy his rolls.

Great sushi option for delivery.
author: Elena N.

description:
Been here a handful of times since they opened and I must say I was impressed by my first visit, but the satisfaction of each visit thereafter has gradually declined. 
Was briefly a fan, not anymore. Most recent visit was last week for dinner and we ordered:

HAMACHI sashimi- most outstanding, fatty; ordered the 3 pc but chef voluntarily cut into 4 pc so that husband and I could have 2 pc each. I personally prefer a thicker slice bc of a better chew/texture but appreciated the attention to detail
UNI nigiris- ordered both from Japan AND Maine; honestly couldn't tell much of a difference; Japan was $8 ea while Maine was $4.5 ea. Recommend Go for the Maine if you must have uni bc the pieces are ridiculously small and NO way worth $8 (does not taste as good as those I had in Japan either)
Hotaru IKA- firefly squid nigiri was okay
Ika sashimi- pretty good, cut into approx. 3/8 in. Thick Threads. I order this almost every time since I like ika
AOEBI shrimp- nigiri okay, fried shrimp head is good; I feel like the shrimps were much smaller than previous times
Sakura SALMON- good, light, soft texture
SALMON SKIN ROLL- salmon skin is very hard and difficult to chew, rice a bit dry
ABURI SABA ROLL- was tasty, scallion tempura inside, Saba outside. 

Everything was edible with a couple items I particularly enjoyed like the hamachi sashimi and aburi Saba roll. However, everything seemed to have shrunk in size (to ridiculous small portions especially the uni nigiri) and they need to improve on their rice game. Rice is equally important as the fish in nigiri/sushi!

Service from the chef is always pretty good, especially when you sit at the counter he may give you his recommendations of the night. However, service of waitstaff service is just alright... Didn't fill my tea (waited for a while and I gave up on asking... just left and gargled down water in my car) and it took quite a while to get our bill. 

If it wasn't for the convenient location from where I live (walking distance), usual no wait if you arrive before 7:30pm, I wouldn't come here again given i could get better sushi/sashimi/rice with the same moneys.
author: Iris H.

description:
5 STARS for the hamachi shots and seared wagyu beef with truffle salt. Both are amazinggg! I also enjoyed their bluefin toro and salmon belly as well.

Their rolls were good, but rolls are rolls to me.. they all taste similar everywhere you go. 

The ankimo was served very warm as if they microwaved it or something. Never had it warm before. Interesting. 

Hamachi carpaccio was pretty good. Beautifully presented.

Service is great. Very fast and friendly.

This place is pretty pricey though.. But totally worth it. If you have not tried daigo's hamachi shots yet.. You are definitely missing out.
author: Esther C.

description:
This place is a gem. 

Very well priced sushi and it's soooo gooddddd. I enjoyed everything I tried. 

5 piece omakase - really good but if you know what you like, you should just order pieces individually. You'll probably save mayyybe a couple of bucks 

Yellowtail nigiri is only 2.5 a piece and it was one of the most enjoyable pieces of sushi I had. Handrolls are real yummy m, too! 

Definitely would come here if you're in the area. It's super tiny so I would suggest coming here during not prime dining hours - we came at 5 right when they opened for dinner and got seated right away.
author: Kelley W.

description: In a sea of Costco-salmon-on-rice mediocrity, we should celebrate the few Japanese spots in the city that rise to a higher standard. There's a place in the world for cheap sushi boat sushi, but also a place for quality spots like this. The Hokkaido scallop nigiri was a standout. Much improved service since my first visit, well poured beer, and not too crowded on a Thursday night. A good value too, factoring in quality. Five stars to my never-been-to-Japan eye. Go tomorrow.
author: Nick C.

description:
I came in craving good uni! But right when I arrived our server said they were out of uni. BUMMER :( Came here with a friend from Michigan and wanted to show her west coast sushi! Upon arriving, our server had three seats open for us at the bar. We ordered yellowtail carpaccio, salmon belly, albacore belly, chu toro, naruto roll, dragon roll and 7oz of Oka!

Everything was pretty fresh. Good variety of fish and selection. I enjoyed my time at the bar. Would I come back here when I'm in SF? Yes! Good sushi for a reasonable price! Our water was always filled and we were always checked up on. I really wish they had uni though because I was CRAVING uni. Other then that, Daigo I'll be back!
author: Sophia V.

description:
If you're looking for really good sushi and sashimi, this place is the place to go! I have been here twice and both experiences were great. The restaurant was a tiny little place with little tables. Very quaint, clean, and nice atmosphere altogether. It is on the pricier side of sushi but it's worth the splurge once in a while when you really want the real deal. 

We ordered the Naruto Roll, butter fish, a few hand rolls, and oysters. Everything tasted fresh and amazing! You even get a free bowl of ice cream with the Yelp check-in! I have tried all three of the ice cream flavors they offer: the green tea, black sesame, and red bean, and the black sesame is interestingly good.
author: Christina C.

description:
Food: 4 stars (Fresh fish)
Service: 2.5 - 3 stars (no customer service)

We came here to celebrate a friend's birthday.  We booked a table for 6 on last weekend.  The restaurant is quite small.  
We are disappointed that they don't have Uni and Ankimo.
We ordered some beers, a Naruto roll, a few sushi roll, sushi and sashimi.

Food was good. On the busy night, it seems like the waiter couldn't handle their customers. :(
author: Mushroom K.

description: I recommend this place 100%. The blue fish toro is so soft & just melts in your mouth! Toro is my favorite & this place exceeded my expectations. The waygu beef is also a must try. Super buttery & savory, not overly salty, very flavorful. Honestly, this place is a must go to. The fish is just so fresh.
author: Bao L.

description: Hands down one of the cleanest, freshest, and tastiest sushi restaurant in San Francisco I've ever tried. Their hamachi shots are bomb!! However, I felt a bit bad die my boyfriend because everything was a bit expensive and we weren't even full. The rolls we ordered didn't particularly stand out to me other than that it was fresh, but I definitely recommend trying their hamachi shots.
author: Elaine C.

description: Really enjoyed sitting at the sushi bar here on a Sunday night and watching the experts go to work on scoring and slicing some delicious-looking fish. The whole team was very friendly and helpful, my water glass stayed full for the most part, and the myriad menu items that I tried were all satisfying and fresh. Other than the overpriced sashimi (which was still almost worth the price, and quite tasty) and the razor-thin slice of (not homemade) green tea cheesecake (at $4 not worth the calories), Daigo sushi knocked it out of the park.
author: Andy L.

description: Went for my birthday last week.  Fantastic all the way.  Service was great nice and great suggestions.  Freshest Uni I've had in a long time.  Everything was wonderful.  Thank you
author: Rob B.

description: This is the hidden gem you've always wanted to find. Excellent selections, service, portions and atmosphere. Go.
author: Geffen R.

description:
For a neighborhood sushi place, this is one of the better quality spots to go to. I'm not really a roll person but their sashimi and nigiri are pretty decent! 

My boyfriend and I came here and we got quite a few of their special nigiri and sashimi moriwase and we weren't disappointed at all. The pieces of sashimi were a bit on the small side but they were quite fresh and delicious. The best pieces were definitely the walu and Chu toro. 

We tried a roll, I forget the name but it was decent but it wasn't anything too special other than the fact that it wasn't over sauced which was good. The hand rolls are also pretty good. The negi toro and unagi avocado hand rolls were delicious! Good amount of fish and not an insane amount of rice. 

If I need a quick sushi fix that's decent I would come here again! 

Total for 2: $90
author: Stella J.

description:
Stopped in for lunch on a Friday afternoon. The restaurant is pretty small, so I could see how dinners could be busy/require a wait. 

We ordered the sashimi moriawase, and 4 nigiri's from the special menu (sea bream, barracuda, ocean trout and blue shrimp).

The sashimi was SOOO delicious. Super fresh, tender, melt in your mouth. I'd say one of the best sashimi plates I've had in a while. The nigiri were on the smaller side, but again, very good. 

Service was quick and friendly.

Decently priced for excellent quality. 

Check in for a free scoop of ice cream!
author: Noelle H.

description:
Cool location, great hole-in-the-wall vibes but the food, surprisingly, not so impressive. Very average quality.

As far as the service, we waited for 30 minutes (even though it's a tiny place and we obviously just came in) and had to get the attention of a server. They seemed out of it, almost irritated that we were there.

If you're simply craving any sushi, this will work.
author: Daria N.

description: High quality sashimi here.  The restaurant is a bit small, but intimate.  It is a bit on the pricey side for how much food you get, but the food was delicious none the less.  I stopped by here after touring around Lands End and it was a nice way to finish my day trip up to San Francisco.
author: Richard L.

description:
Came in on a Saturday night around 8 p.m. and to our surprise, there were only two other tables in the restaurant. We walked in and we're told to sit wherever we liked, which is always nice. As soon as we sat down, the server brought us menus and tea shortly after. We did have to gesture to the servers that we were ready to order since they had huddled at the register chatting. No big deal though, service was super attentive throughout - tea and water were constantly filled, plates were cleared away almost instantly, and our server asked us how we liked the meal at the end. 

Tuna tataki salad: HUGE. Comes with a good amount of tuna, which is great. This is spicy, so the bf couldn't eat too much of it. 
Tuna sashimi: I say the slices were average in size and thickness. 
Naruto roll: The bf really liked this, but I thought it was okay. 
Nigiri: Sooo fresh! We ordered the hamachi, albacore, walu, and hon maguro. It was all delicious and I was tempted to order more even though we would not have finished it. 

Prices are a bit on the pricier side; our bill came out to be 69 before tip. But I think it was worth it and definitely will be back for the fresh fish.
author: Doris K.

description:
My friend and I were super excited to try this place out! Everything looks so fresh and mouth-watering! There was no wait when we got there so we were seated right away. The restaurant is small and cozy, so it might be a good idea to call and ask about the wait, and make reservations if you need to. Mid-way through our dinner, a group who had reservations came in and we were asked if it was okay for them to move us to a smaller table. We were fine with that, since the waiters were pretty nice about it. I didn't expect this, but at the end of our meal they even gave us a complimentary green tea cheesecake for dessert! Overall, I would rate their service a 4.5/5.

- Hamachi Shots 5/5 
Favorite dish of the night! Everything about this was excellent! Flavors and presentation were on point!
- Uni nigiri & Ikura nigiri 3.5/5
Just lacking in a bit of taste and the piece was a bit tiny
- Nigiri Moriawase 4/5
Loved this dish as well! All the fish were absolutely delicious! Very fresh and melts in your mouth! The rice was moist and had a nice, light acidity.
- Naruto Roll 5/5
This was also another one of my favorites! Very unique, as I've never seen or tried any rolls like this. Overall the flavors were great! You should definitely try this.
- Tokyo Cowboy Roll 3.5/5
- Green Tea Cheesecake 4/5
I've never tried this flavor of cheesecake before, but it's pretty good! The slice they gave us was pretty small, so this is definitely a splurge dish!

Don't forget to check-in on Yelp and get free ice cream! Hehe!
author: Evonne C.

description: Daigo is amazing! Fish quality is excellent, and a very nice staff. Not a "cheap sushi" restaurant, but very reasonable price for the quality of the sushi you receive. The Moriawase Nigiri is a must, and gives you an excellent sample of tuna, yellowtail, scallop and salmon, all preseasoned to perfection. The restaurant is on the small side, so make sure to call for a reservation during busy times!
author: Nate T.

description: The setting is typical small SF venue but the food is nothing typical. We ordered 10 piece Omakase each and the sushi were fresh and well presented. We decided to have another round of 5 more pieces. All come in tasteful and tasty. Highly recommended restaurant.
author: John C.

description:
I am Sasuke Uchiha. I journeyed from across the land in search of Naruto Umezaki, my lifelong nemesis. I have now arrived in this town called Richmond....could this be the legendary Hidden Village in the Fog? I can see no further than the Daigo Sushi shop five paces ahead. Very well, I will inquire about Naruto there first. 

"Welcome to Daigo Sushi, you can sit by the bar or at a table."

I am here for Naruto Umezaki. 

"Naruto Umezaki..? Oh! You mean the Naruto Roll. Yeah we have that, coming right up. Hey are you okay, man? Your eyes look a little bloodshot."

Bloodshot? This fool does not even know of my Sharingan, but yet he has the whereabouts of Naruto... how could this be...?

*Chef cuts sushi*

Impossible! That man is wielding a sword from the Seven Ninja Swordsman of the Mist! It all makes sense now, the reason why this town is so foggy. My sharingan sees that he is using the sword to cut the fish to perfection. And he is chanting some sort of Jutsu as he is cutting... he is chanting "One Omakase Coming Right Up." Blast it, I must be extra careful of these Daigo Ninjas.

"Here is your Naruto Roll."

Is this really Naruto? Is he disguising himself as one of Choji's snacks? I must take a bite.

The fish swirls around with the cucumber just as the shape of a naruto. Undeniably delicious, perfected by a slight hint of oil... But only a master could have crafted the perfect swirl of this sushi. A master with the skill of Rasengan! Naruto is near, I must leave to find him at once!

"Sir! You can't leave yet, you haven't paid the bill."

Fool! Do you not know who I am? MANGEKYO SHARINGAN!!

"Sir, I don't know nothing 'bout this mako shotgun thing you're saying, but staring at me like that will not stop me from calling the police if you don't pay."

A Summoning Jutsu for the police!? You win this time, Daigo Ninjas of the Village Hidden in the Fog. You win.

*Takes out Naruto's Froggy Wallet*
author: Ringo M.

description:
Extremely Delicious. 

I tend to believe that one can get good sushi all over the City -- not that every sushi place is good, but simply, you don't have to go far to find a good place for sushi. 

I happened to be in the Richmond at dinner time and decided on this place based upon Yelp. Yelp was not wrong!

My 10 year old daughter and I sat at the sushi bar. I ordered a 5 piece nigiri chef's choice, and was presented with 5 perfect little jewels of fresh fish. The chef explained that he had already spiced them with soy and wasabi, so I wouldn't need to use more. (This reminds me of how fine French restaurants don't put salt and pepper on the table.). Each morsel was absolutely, perfectly delicious. The flavors were varied but perfect. Really great fish!

It's a small, corner place. Atmosphere was pleasant - on the darker side (as many places along Clement are overly bright). The service was friendly and attentive. 

They forgot to bring a beer I ordered, but I forgot about it too -- the fish was so good!
author: Brent D.

description:
Found this neighborhood gem sushi restaurant in the Richmond district as we were looking for a place to eat, and once again thanks to the Yelpers, we picked this restaurant based on the great reviews. The restaurant is very small and unassuming and has only about 10 small tables. Started the dinner with Edamame, Beef Tataki, and Tofu salad. All the appetizers were great with very subtle/delicate taste and not over powered by soy sauce like many other places. 

We continued with the series of sushi rolls: Naruto roll, Hamachi Jalapeño roll, Dragon roll, Rainbow roll, Spider roll, Sweet potato roll, Salmon avocado hand roll,  and Tokyo cowboy hand roll. Each was unique with very fresh sashimi. The staff was friendly and helpful and served the selections one at a time with a steady pace which was great. A definite must try for sushi lovers. 

They also have a very large drink menu, but since we are not drinkers, cannot comment on that
author: Mehrnaz H.

description: Told us that the wait would be 10-15 minutes but even after 45 minutes we weren't seated. We were a group of three without reservation but called ahead of time to ask if it would be a long wait. We stood outside in the cold even though a table of two had opened up. We ended up leaving after 45 minutes of waiting and got the call 15 minutes after so the total wait would've been an hour total versus the 15 minutes they originally told us. Definitely recommend making a reservation before going.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
4 stars for food, 1 star for service. 

Made a reservation a few days prior to going to dinner for a group of 4. Spoke with someone and was very happy to get the reservation as I knew that its a small space with few tables. Arrived on time on Friday night and was told I didn't have a reservation. I told them that I'd made it just a few days prior and they said they didn't get the message. I told them that I didn't leave a message, I spoke with an employee. They apologized and wrote us down on the list. 

After over an hour of waiting outside, they had a table for us. They seated us away from the door, which I was grateful for as were thawing from the past hour. After a couple of minutes at our table, the hostess came by and explained that they needed to move us to another table. As an apology for the inconvenience they brought us sake. Which, you know, is a great idea to give four females that have been waiting for dinner for so long. An appetizer would have been much more appreciated but at least the sake warmed us up.

The sushi was very good, not innovative or extraordinary in any way but great quality fish. 

If you are in a party of two, I'd still recommend coming to Daigo but if you have 3 or more, make sure you have a reservation. And then call back to confirm it. Maybe twice.
author: Ilana V.

description:
Nice tiny neighborhood place. Fish is always fresh and delicious. Service is friendly. I normally don't go on for "special" rolls, but I like their Tokyo Cowboy Roll write a bit. 

This review is currently shorter than most. Maybe I should add more later.
author: Chris P.

description: My favorite restaurant in America. Best sushi I've ever had. So good I wish it didn't exist. I could never live near this place because I would spend all my money here, even though it is very reasonably priced.
author: Joshua D.

description:
Great sushi great service very creative rolls
Eaten here many times and they get better and better
Huge variety of delicious fishes
The waitress and all the staff seem concerned that you are having a pleasant experiencr
author: Helen K.

description:
TORO MELTS LIKE BUTTER!!!!
(4.5 stars)

One of the best toro I've ever had. FISH BELLY, get in my belly!!!!!

- FOOD, deliciousness 
- PRICES, decent/depends 
- SERVICE, good
- AMBIANCE, small and clean

You pay for QUALITY!! They have a "Today's Special" menu that changes daily based on what the supplier brings in. ALWAYS order from this menu. This is not the typical sushi joint where the rolls are covered in sauces, nor it is a sushi joint where you can order teriyaki and all that extra garbage. This is a TRUE and LEGIT sushi joint. 

HEFER STATS. 

HAMACHI SHOT ($6) - that has got to be the loveliest hamachi shot I've had (beats the one at Alexander steakhouse). It had finely diced hamachi, finely chopped onion, raw quail egg yolk, crispy rice balls (crumbs), sliver of avocado, pinch of fish eggs as garnish, and truffle ponzu. The truffle wasn't over powering and enhanced the flavors. It was just lovely! Highly recommend. 

HAMACHI CARPACCIO ($10) - thinly sliced hamachi, jalapeño, tobiko, and garlic ponzu. It was laid out like the beef Tataki, on a long plate. Beautiful color, crackin taste!!! The hamachi was like velvet with little hints of heat. I could do without the fish eggs... The hamachi is just fine without or with. Good stuff!

BEEF TATAKI ($10) - seared filet Mignon and Tataki sauce (think it has jalapeño flavor), The beef was laid ontop of raw arugula. The slices of filet Mignon were delicious; tender and flavorful. If you take a bite with the arugula you get the sharp taste on the after taste. Flavor, savory of the meat, and a nice tangy and spice of heat from the jalapeño. Highly recommend.

TORO TASTING ($15.5) - this was on the today's special menu; not always available but if it is... Order it without hesitation!!! 4 pieces only but the belly (toro) is the best part. The toro tasting came from 4 different fish (albacore toro, salmon toro, blue fin toro, and yellowtail toro). MELTED IN MY MOUTH!!!!! Hands down, that was the best I've ever had. Highly recommend.

NARUTO ($9) - 4 pieces. spicy tuna, sake, hamachi, and avocado wrapped in cucumber wrapper  with ponzu. This was one of their special rolls. This is one of their popular items. You can see three different fishes folded within the cucumber wrap. The cucumber wrap gives this roll a nice crunch and the ponzu helps digest the roll. Highly recommend.

ISAKI ($6) - this was on today's special. 2 pieces of three line grunt from Japan. The fish was light in taste and not as tender as is imagine. There isn't much creaminess in this order and nothing exciting. It wasn't "terrible" it just wasn't awesome. Do not really recommend. 

NEGIHAMA ($3.50) - 6 pieces. hamachi and scallops. This was a roll and came in six tiny pieces. Although it looks simple, it was yummy and I liked it. Didn't have any crazy/colorful sauces, just pieces and dipping sauce. Who needs garbage sauce to cover quality. Highly Recommend. 

GREEN TEA ICE CREAM (free) - save yourself $2.50 if you check-in. You can chose other flavors but green tea is yummy. Refreshing after a meal. Green tea is always my first pick in ice cream at this place. 

BLACK SESAME ICE CREAM - they have the best black sesame ice cream!! The sesame taste is not overpowering and the ice cream itself is very creamy. I am a fan. 

Will I be back? DUH!!! I am duke for a reason.

JABA APPROVED... Until the next review!!!
author: Jane A.

description: amazing deal on omakase. we had 10 pieces for 2, supplemented with a few O-toro and wagyu pieces for fun, and split a carafe of sake for less than what  many downtown sushi spots charge for one omakase alone. the quality was very fresh and tasty, and I loved the no-frills, intimate seating.
author: R D.

description: We put our name down for dinner on an extremely cold, windy, and rainy night. and they us it would be a short wait, no more than 10-15 minutes. After waiting half an hour, I went in to check but again he said 10-15 min. After 50 minutes of standing in the freezing cold ( there's no space to wait on the inside) we were fed up. This place isn't worth the wait. And they've permanently lost a neighborhood customer who used to frequent once a month. Not worth the mess of an experience and not cheap either.
author: Brenda C.

description:
3.5 stars. I came here with a few friends for dinner tonight to celebrate a belated birthday.We ordered a few rolls for dinner. I ordered the Baked Salmon Roll and tried both the Tempura Roll and Spider Roll. Out of three rolls that I tried, I thought that the Baked Salmon Roll tasted the best. 

The Baked Salmon Roll is basically a baked California roll filled with avocado and imitation crab meat topped with salmon and drizzled with spicy mayo. I loved that it's definitely fresh. This roll took the longest to make, which is understandable. I loved that the entire roll worked well together. It is on the pricey side with 8 pieces for $12.

The Tempura Roll came with just 6 pieces for $6.50. Shrimp tempura with avocado wrapped into a sushi roll. This roll didn't amaze me and I mostly tasted the batter of the tempura more than anything else.

The Spider Roll was pretty good too. The basic soft shell crab wrapped with cucumber and avocado then drizzled with teriyaki sauce. When you bite into this roll, the first thing you notice is the soft shell crab. It's crunchy and delicious. However, I feel like it's all I noticed too. It's as if I'm only eating the soft shell crab rather than as a roll. 

I was a little bit disappointed after all the reviews I read. However, since I don't eat raw fish, I can't review their other rolls. I do believe they are known for their fresh fish. For me, I feel their cooked rolls are overpriced for the amount we received. The rolls are smaller than other sushi places that I've been to.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Ordered the 10 piece nigiri omakase here for $40. There is a wide selection of fish from Japan that you can't normally find in San Francisco. While the fish was fresh, the portions were a bit on the sad side. I could have ate at least 30 pieces before feeling completely full, and I'm a 5'2 105 pound Asian girl. 

Highlights were:
- Horse Mackerel Nigiri
- Blue Shrimp Nigiri
- Salmon Belly Nigiri
- Chu Toro (Medium Fatty Tuna)

The nigiri comes brushed with soy sauce and wasabi like some of the more traditional joints in Japan so dipping isn't necessary.

As usual, we chose to sit at the sushi bar so that we could be close to the action and talk to the sushi chefs. Once we found out that one of the chefs who is also the owner is Taiwanese, conversation began to flow. Turns out his uncle owns a completely different type of sushi resstaurant down in Mountain View, which we were all very familiar with - the AYCE sushi placed called Sushi 85. 

They also serve you free ice cream at the end! :)
author: Catherine C.

description: I was served hamachi in a roll that was completely rancid and had fish scales in it that I had to spit out into a napkin. I am a cook professionally and know what bad fish looks like. From touching a tiny piece of the fish to see how slimy it was I cannot wash the  fishy smell off of my fingers. Absolutely disgusting and the chef who put that out should be ashamed. Service was good.
author: Ian M.

description:
I forgot to leave a review for this place and I visited this place months ago, but still remember the experience as if it was yesterday. XD Came with my girlfriend and was seated quickly even though we didn't make reservations. This was after finding out the other sushi place we planned to go to wasn't available. 

We sat at the bar and order the Naruto roll which was delicious as well as their Hamachi shots which was hot damn good! We also ordered nigiri and even though they were all very fresh and tasty the WAGYU stood out to me the most. So juicy, warm, and flavorful. The nigiri menu had the best choices in my opinion since they had more than just the average fish Americans enjoy. The staff and chefs were young which was a nice change up. 

The place is small so I don't recommend big parties, but definitely for dates. It's a nice and cozy place along with a friendly staff which was also attentive. 

At the end of our dinner we got ice cream on the house and it was so creamy, soft, and not to mention hit the spot. Maybe it was because we spent a good amount of money, but either way I'll take free ice cream any day!
author: Oscar L.

description: I had high expectations but I honestly have never had worse sushi and I'm from landlocked Utah! The rice was horrible, fish was questionable.
author: Riley Jo H.

description:
Cute and cozy little corner restaurant. The staff was not the friendliest nor helpful. Dookie faces all around. 

The food was only average. We ordered the 10 piece nigiri omakase and I did not leave full or satisfied. The fish was not as fresh as I hoped it would be and the portions were even more disappointing. I would much rather brave the wait at Amami for better quality food. 

The restaurant overall was average. It's always nice to check out the local joints but I have no desire to return.

No flies.

First yelp review. CHECK! =)
author: Miles L.

description:
WOW. This is now one of my favorite Japanese restaurants. This hidden gem, tucked away in an obscure corner of Clement street, is home to some of the most fresh, unique, and tasty rolls in the city! 

I very much enjoyed: 
-Hamachi Shot with onions, a quail egg, truffle ponzu and rice balls 
-tempura green onion w/filet minion, shittake 
-tempura tuna roll,
-baked salmon roll
-free ice cream for Yelpers

The combinations of flavors, presentation, and portions left me at a loss for words, as I was happily inhaling the sushi. It's a little pricey but trust- it's worth every penny!
author: Stephen D.

description:
Small in portion but packed with flavor, Daigo delicately presented the 10-piece chef's choice along with the Baked Salmon roll on beautiful onyx-colored wares. All rich in texture and flavor, the flavors were all very light, distinct, and, very fresh. 

Ice cream is generous, varietal, and a perfect way to end a fantastic experience with friends. I recommend calling thirty in advance to secure a table so you don't wait out in the... fog.
author: Ryan K.

description:
In search for a Japanese restaurant for a cousin date and this place was the deal.  The menu is simple and the place is small but there are table seats and there are bar seats. The waiter was real nice and attentive and patient with us when we were waiting on one more person.  We ordered the following:

HAMACHI SHOTS:
Six bucks each shot, with quail egg, red onion, hamachi pieces, and some crunchy pieces I cannot recall in ponzu sauce.  I downed this shot and man was it yummy!! I could have another but I needed to save the tummy for more yummy food. 

HAMACHI CAPACCIO:
Slices of HAMACHI with jalapeño slices, red onion, and tobiko on top drizzled with what looks like sriracha.  One of my cousins LOVE HAMACHI and she loved this dish, I would too if I could handle the jalapeño, I did try this and it was good but so spicy!!

NARUTO ROLL:
As everyone has already said, this roll is top notch! Thinly sliced cucumber wrapped around spicy tuna with HAMACHI, avocado, and salmon. The ponzu sauce that this roll comes with is good enough that you don't need soy sauce to dip unlike other rolls.  This roll is a must try. 4 piece this roll. 

WHITE TUNA:
